message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clear rush of fluid from the vagina suggests rupture of membranes, while the abdominal pain and contractions suggest preterm labor. Betamethasone, a corticosteroid, is used to accelerate fetal lung maturation and decrease the risk of respiratory distress syndrome when preterm delivery is expected within the next 7 days. Terbutaline may be used to delay preterm labor, but is not the best first step in this case. RhoGAM is used in cases of Rh incompatibility, which is not indicated in this patient. Expectant management can lead to significant morbidity and mortality in both the mother and fetus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clear rush of fluid and painful abdominal contractions suggest preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM) and preterm labor. Betamethasone is given to accelerate fetal lung maturation and decrease the risk of respiratory distress syndrome in preterm infants. Expectant management should only be done in stable patients with no signs of labor and no evidence of infection. Terbutaline can be used for tocolysis in preterm labor, but in this case, the patient has already ruptured membranes. RhoGAM is used when a Rh-negative mother is carrying a Rh-positive fetus.

We refer to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists guidelines for help. The presentation suggests preterm labor with premature rupture of membranes. Betamethasone is recommended for fetal lung maturation in cases of threatened preterm delivery before 34 weeks. Terbutaline and RhoGAM are not indicated in this case, and expectant management may pose risks to the fetus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing contractions and has ruptured membranes, indicating preterm labor. Betamethasone is a corticosteroid that can promote fetal lung maturity and is the best next step in management. Terbutaline is a tocolytic agent that can be used to stop contractions, but it is not the best initial step in this case. RhoGAM is used in cases of Rh incompatibility, which is not established in this patient. Expectant management is not appropriate in this case as preterm labor increases the risk of complications for both the mother and the baby.

We refer to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) guidelines for help. The patient's symptoms and physical exam findings suggest preterm labor with premature rupture of membranes (PROM). Betamethasone is recommended for fetal lung maturation in cases of anticipated preterm delivery with intact membranes. Terbutaline is used as a tocolytic to slow or stop labor, but it is not the best next step in this scenario. RhoGAM is indicated for Rh-negative mothers with Rh-positive fetuses, which is not applicable to this case. Expectant management is not appropriate in this case due to the risk of preterm delivery and potential complications for the fetus.

We refer to MedlinePlus for help. The clear fluid rush from the vagina and painful abdominal contractions suggest preterm labor. Betamethasone is a glucocorticoid that can accelerate fetal lung maturity and reduce the risk of respiratory distress syndrome in preterm infants. It is the best next step in management. Terbutaline is a tocolytic agent and may be used to stop or slow down preterm labor. RhoGAM is not indicated as the patient's blood type is not provided and this is not relevant to the management of preterm labor. Expectant management is appropriate for certain cases of preterm labor, but in this case, the patient is in the 35th week and management to prevent preterm delivery is warranted.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical picture suggests that the patient is experiencing preterm labor with premature rupture of membranes. Betamethasone administration is indicated to help prevent respiratory distress syndrome in the newborn. Terbutaline is used to stop uterine contractions, but it is not indicated in this case. RhoGAM is used if the patient is Rh-negative and the baby is Rh-positive. Expectant management is not appropriate in this case as preterm labor can result in significant morbidity and mortality to both mother and baby.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clear fluid and painful abdominal contractions suggest preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM) and threatened preterm labor. The patient is in her 35th week of pregnancy, so her preterm labor should be managed with Betamethasone, a glucocorticoid that can help accelerate fetal lung maturity and reduce the incidence of respiratory distress syndrome. Terbutaline is used to treat bronchial asthma and not indicated in this case. RhoGAM is a medication given to Rh-negative mothers to prevent Rh sensitization, which is not relevant in this case. Expectant management can lead to an increased risk of neonatal morbidity/mortality.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and clear rush of fluid suggest preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM). Betamethasone is given to women with PPROM in order to help fetal lung maturity and reduce the risk of respiratory distress syndrome. Terbutaline can be used for preterm labor, but the clear rush of fluid indicates PPROM, not labor. RhoGAM is used for Rh-negative mothers and is not relevant to this case. Expectant management is not the best option as there is risk of infection and fetal complications with PPROM.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's clear rush of fluid from the vagina and painful contractions suggest preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM), which increases the risk of preterm delivery. Betamethasone is a corticosteroid used to improve fetal lung maturation and reduce the incidence of respiratory distress syndrome in preterm infants. Therefore, it is the best next step in management. Terbutaline is a tocolytic agent used to inhibit contractions, but it is not indicated for PPROM. RhoGAM is used to prevent Rh isoimmunization in Rh-negative women, but it is not relevant in this case. Expectant management is an option, but it carries risks of maternal and fetal complications and is not the best next step for this patient.
